page.title: 07The history of Sebergham
page.content: It is not known for certain what was the origin of the word Sebergham. It seems to have been originally Seavyburg, Sievyburg or Sievyhill. The lack of natural drainage favoured the growth of rushes or sieves and perhaps hence the name. Alternatively it is thought it might be a shieling or shepherds summer pasture in a clearing of the forest of Inglewood. The forest of Inglewood was at one time a royal hunting forest. Thus there are few villages within the forest that stretches from Penrith to Carlisle and West to Wigton. Consequently farms and houses tend to be scattered and isolated. Sebergham, formerly known as Sebergham Bridge, is one of relatively few villages within the confines of the forest.
